question: Which NCAA Division I basketball team does Jeff Churchill play for?

content.source_1:
**Breaking News: Saint Francis University Alumnus Jeff Churchill Shines in NCAA Division I Men's Basketball**

In a remarkable display of athletic prowess, Jeff Churchill, a former college basketball player, has made a name for himself in the prestigious NCAA Division I men's basketball league. Churchill, who donned the Red Flash jersey from 1995 to 1998, has left an indelible mark on the Saint Francis University basketball program. According to NCAA records, Churchill was an integral part of the Saint Francis University men's basketball team, competing in the Northeast Conference (NEC) of the NCAA Division I. During his tenure, the team demonstrated significant improvement, with Churchill's impressive skills on the court playing a crucial role in their success. "Jeff was an exceptional player who brought a high level of energy and dedication to our program," said Bob Thurston, Saint Francis University's former head coach. "He was a true leader on and off the court, and his contributions to our team's growth were invaluable." Data from the NCAA reveals that during Churchill's playing career, the Saint Francis University men's basketball team showed a notable increase in wins, with a winning percentage of .533 in the 1996-1997 season, the highest during his time at the university. Churchill's achievements on the court are a testament to his hard work and commitment to the sport. "Jeff's passion for basketball was evident in every game he played," said teammate and close friend, Mike Wilson. "He was a true competitor who always gave his all, and his presence on the court inspired us to push ourselves to be better players." The NCAA Division I men's basketball league is comprised of 358 colleges and universities, with Saint Francis University being one of the esteemed institutions that compete at this level. Churchill's participation in this elite league is a reflection of his exceptional talent and dedication to the sport. In conclusion, the evidence overwhelmingly supports the claim that Jeff Churchill played in the NCAA Division I men's basketball league during his time at Saint Francis University. His impressive skills, leadership, and contributions to the team's success are a testament to his remarkable athletic career.
content.source_2: As the sun dipped below the rolling hills of Loretto, Pennsylvania, the Saint Francis University campus buzzed with excitement. It was a chilly winter evening in 1996, and the Red Flash women's basketball team was gearing up to take on their arch-rivals, the Mount St. Mary's Mountaineers. In the midst of the pre-game frenzy, a tall, lanky figure emerged from the locker room, his bright blue eyes scanning the crowd with a quiet confidence. Jeff Churchill, the team's star shooting guard, was a familiar face in the DeGol Arena. For three years, he had been a mainstay of the Red Flash lineup, known for his silky smooth jump shot and tenacious defense. As he made his way to the court, the Saint Francis faithful erupted into cheers, their "Let's go Jeff!" chants echoing off the rafters. As the teams took to the court for warm-ups, the NCAA Division I women's basketball logo emblazoned on the scorer's table seemed to gleam with an extra intensity, a reminder that this was the highest level of collegiate competition. The Saint Francis University Red Flash, proud members of the Northeast Conference, were determined to make a statement against their opponents from Maryland. As the game tipped off, Jeff Churchill was everywhere, darting between defenders with ease, his quick release and precision shooting leaving the Mountaineers scrambling to keep up. The Red Flash bench, a sea of crimson and white, was electric, with Coach Susan Robinson-Fruchtl exhorting her team to push the tempo. In the midst of the fast-paced action, Jeff's teammates couldn't help but marvel at his unique blend of skill and athleticism. "He's got the heart of a lion," whispered point guard Rachel Schneider to power forward Amy Kuhns, as Jeff drove to the basket, drawing a foul from the Mountaineers' towering center. As the final buzzer sounded, the Red Flash celebrated a hard-fought 75-68 victory, Jeff Churchill's 23 points and 7 rebounds leading the way.
